Federated Learning with Server Learning: Enhancing Performance for Non-IID Data

Van Sy Mai, Richard J. La, Tao Zhang V. S. Mai and T. Zhang are with the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), Gaithersburg, MD 20899, USA. Email: {vansy.mai, tao.zhang}@nist.gov. R.J. La is with NIST and the University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742, USA. Email: hyongla@umd.edu. Any mention of commercial products in this paper is for information only; it does not imply any recommendation or endorsement by NIST. U.S. Government work not protected by U.S. copyright
Abstract

Federated Learning (FL) has emerged as a means of distributed learning using local data stored at clients with a coordinating server. Recent studies showed that FL can suffer from poor performance and slower convergence when training data at clients are not independent and identically distributed. Here we consider a new complementary approach to mitigating this performance degradation by allowing the server to perform auxiliary learning from a small dataset. Our analysis and experiments show that this new approach can achieve significant improvements in both model accuracy and convergence time even when the server dataset is small and its distribution differs from that of the aggregated data from all clients.

I Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) is a recent paradigm in which multiple clients collaborate under the coordination of a central server to train machine learning (ML) models [13]. A key advantage is that clients need not send their local data to any central sever or share their data with each other. Performing learning where the data is generated (or collected) is becoming necessary as a large and growing amount of data is created at the network edge and cannot all be forwarded to any central location due to many factors such as network capacity constraints, latency requirements, and data privacy concerns [4].

In its basic form, FL trains a global model for all clients based on the following high-level iterative procedure. At each global round: 1) the central server selects a subset of clients and shares the current global model with them, 2) each selected client updates the model using only its local data and forwards the updated model to the central server, and 3) the central server aggregates the updated local models from the clients to update the global model. This process is repeated until certain convergence criteria are satisfied.

Background: Conventional FL techniques, such as the well-known Federated Averaging (FedAvg) algorithm [22], carry out model aggregation by averaging the model parameters received from the clients. This performs well when clients have access to independent and identically distributed (IID) training samples. In practice, however, the local data available to the clients often do not satisfy this IID assumption for different reasons. For instance, clients may collect data from different sources, using different tools, under different conditions, or only have access to partial or biased data, which can cause the distributions of the samples or features at different clients to differ considerably. Such divergences are also referred to as drifts or shifts, and can take different forms [13].

Large divergences can cause conventional FL techniques to suffer from poor model performance and slow training convergence [6, 8, 12, 14, 18, 33]. For example, feature divergence, where the distributions of features differ at different clients, may cause local models to focus on different features or even use different feature representations. Non-IID training data can also cause clients to optimize their local models toward local optima that can differ significantly from global optima. This can further cause the weights of clients’ local models to diverge [21, 33]. As a result, simply averaging local models may not move the aggregated model toward a global optimum.

Recently, growing efforts have been devoted to improving FL performance for non-IID data. The following are several representative categories of approaches.

∙∙\bullet Personalization: Clients personalize their local models to perform well on their local data [6, 11, 16, 17, 26]. Personalization can be for individual clients or groups of clients (e.g., clients that have similar training data or contribute similar model updates to the server) [3] [9]. Many real-world applications, however, desire a common model for all clients. For example, consider autonomous vehicles (AVs) in different geographical regions learning to recognize stop signs. The snow-covered stop signs in northeast United States can look very different from those along the sunny southern country roads. Since cars can travel anywhere, they will benefit from a model that can work well everywhere.

∙∙\bullet Changing how clients learn or contribute: Several approaches aim to better align the objectives of clients that can diverge due to non-IID training data, e.g., [24, 30]. Clients may use Batch Normalization to alleviate local model divergence caused by non-IID data [19]. Batch Normalization [10] has been used in deep learning to mitigate the impact of domain shifts (i.e., differences between training data distribution and test data distribution). Various methods have also been proposed to choose a subset of the clients to participate in each round of FL to counterbalance distribution shifts [25, 32].

∙∙\bullet Changing how the server aggregates local models: This approach alters the aggregation method of local models based on, e.g., their distances to an estimated global model baseline [28], or additional client states or control variates [14].

∙∙\bullet Lifelong learning techniques: These techniques treat the learning at each client as a separate task and learn these tasks sequentially using a single model without forgetting the previously learned tasks [13].

Motivation: Our main observation is that these existing FL algorithms do not consider the central server as a learner or assume that the server has no training data. In practice, however, the server can and often have access to some training data. For example, the server may receive data from sensors and testing devices that do not participate in the learning process. It may have synthetic data obtained from simulation (or emulation) and digital twins. The server may also receive some raw data directly from the clients; this is often required to, for example, support system monitoring and diagnosis.

Consider again AVs, as an example, which need ML models to recognize objects. Today, two main sources of data are used to train and test such models. First, test vehicles are used to scout selected areas to collect real-world data. Note that this typically imposes no privacy concerns. It, however, may require large fleets of test vehicles, take years to accomplish, incur heavy costs, and yet still fail to collect enough data to cover the vast range of possible learning needs [31]. Therefore, the AV industry is increasingly relying on a second source of data – synthetic data, typically generated in the cloud – to extend model training and testing scopes. Going forward, when some AVs participate in FL, a small fleet of test vehicles, which may not all participate in FL, can still be used to collect and send data to the server to compensate the data that the FL clients can collect.

Sharing a common IID training dataset with all clients (so that each client will train its local model on its local data plus this common dataset) has been shown to improve FL performance with non-IID data [13, 17, 33]. But, this method, which we refer to as FL with data sharing or simply data sharing, also increases clients’ workload, making them less suitable for resource-constrained devices. More importantly, it is often impractical for clients to share data with each other due to privacy concerns, network bandwidth constraints, and latency requirements. We will show that it is unnecessary to share such common datasets among clients, as comparable or better performance can be achieved by having the server learn from the same dataset.

Several recent works have considered server learning with some centralized data, e.g., hybrid training [27], mixed FL [1], and FL with server learning [20]. However, [27] analyzes only the case where both clients’ data and server data are IID and their algorithm requires all clients to participate in every round. Similarly, [1] assumes IID client data and considers server’s role as a regularizer. In contrast, [20] focuses on FL with non-IID client data. In this paper, we build upon our work in [20] to study the idea of using server learning to enhance FL on non-IID data and provide both analytical and experimental results showing that this approach can be effective under certain conditions. Therefore, the primary focus of our study and reported analysis are fundamentally different from those in [1] and [27].

Contributions: We consider a new FL algorithm that incorporates server learning to improve performance on non-IID data. Specifically, the server collects a small amount of data, learns from it, and distills the knowledge into the global model incrementally during the FL process. We refer to this method as Federated Learning with Server Learning (FSL). Our main contributions can be summarized as follows:

∙∙\bullet Through our analysis and experimental studies, we show that FSL can significantly improve the performance in both final accuracy and convergence time when clients have non-IID data. Also, only a small amount of data is needed at the server for FSL to improve performance, even when the server data distribution deviates from that of the aggregated data stored at the clients. As expected, the training performance improves as such distribution divergence diminishes.

∙∙\bullet By incorporating server learning with FL in an incremental fashion, we will demonstrate that FSL significantly accelerates the learning process when the current model is far from any (locally) optimal model.

∙∙\bullet FSL is simple and can be tuned relatively easily, even when the server dataset is relatively small. Compared to FL, FSL adds only a local learning component to the server and does not affect the clients. Thus, FSL has the same per-round communication overhead as FL while practically requiring to tune only one additional parameter, which is the weight given to server’s loss function. Our experimental studies show that the performance improvement of FSL remains significant for a relatively large range of this weight.

In our experiments, FSL consistently outperforms the data sharing method in [33], suggesting that sharing common datasets with clients might be unnecessary. We also demonstrate that by employing a small amount of data from either a few clients or other data sources (including synthetic data) for server learning, FSL can achieve similar (and often better) performance compared to FedDyn [7] and SCAFFOLD [14], while enjoying a significant boost in learning rate at the beginning.

Preliminary results of this paper appeared in [20], where only the main algorithm and limited experimental results using IID server data were reported. In this paper, we provide a theoretical analysis of FSL and more extensive experimental evaluations, including a comparison with SCAFFOLD algorithm using non-IID server data.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. The problem formulation and our algorithm are given in § II. Main convergence results are presented in § III, followed by experimental evaluations in § IV. Conclusions are given in § V. All the proofs and additional numerical results can be found in our technical report in Appendices A and B, respectively.

II Problem Formulation and Our Approach

In this section, we first present our problem formulation in connection with the data sharing approach, and then delineate the FSL algorithm aimed at coping with non-IID data.

II-A Problem Formulation

Consider the following ML problem in which we train a model to minimize an empirical loss:

Having the server learn, rather than sharing training samples among the clients, avoids practical issues such as extra communication overheads, long and unpredictable network delays, and privacy concerns. In what follows, we will use (5) to facilitate our discussion and emphasize that our analysis applies directly to (6).

II-B FSL Algorithm

We assume that the server has access to dataset 𝒟0subscript𝒟0\mathcal{D}_{0} and will augment FL with what the server learns over 𝒟0subscript𝒟0\mathcal{D}_{0}. As stated earlier, we refer to this approach as Federated Learning with Server Learning or FSL.

There are several ways to incorporate server learning (SL) into FL. One is to treat the server as a regular client that participates in every round of FL process [29]: During each global round, the server updates the current global model using 𝒟0subscript𝒟0\mathcal{D}_{0} and then aggregates it with the updated models reported by the clients. We call this approach non-incremental SL. One issue with non-incremental SL is that the weight for the server would be very small when n0≪nmuch-less-thansubscript𝑛0𝑛n_{0}\ll n, which means that the server’s contributions, based on its learning from 𝒟0subscript𝒟0\mathcal{D}_{0}, to the global model will be minor. Moreover, this approach fails to exploit the good quality of 𝒟0subscript𝒟0\mathcal{D}_{0}, especially when its distribution is close to that of 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. This issue can be partially alleviated by increasing the weight given to the server’s model in the aggregation step.

These observations motivate us to consider an incremental learning scheme in which the server performs additional learning over dataset 𝒟0subscript𝒟0\mathcal{D}_{0} based on the aggregated model, as shown in Algorithm 1 below in more detail. In particular, lines 1–9 of Algorithm 1 are the same as in a conventional FL algorithm [22], where in each global round t𝑡t, each selected client i𝑖i (1) receives the current global model xtsubscript𝑥𝑡x_{t} from the server, (2) performs K𝐾K steps of the Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD) algorithm using its local data 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} (LocalSGD) with learning rate ηlsubscript𝜂𝑙\eta_{l}, and (3) returns to the server its update Δt(i)superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑡𝑖\Delta_{t}^{(i)}. The server then combines its current model xtsubscript𝑥𝑡x_{t} with the updates from the clients using some weight ηg>0subscript𝜂𝑔0\eta_{g}>0 (lines 8–9). It then uses the resulting updated model to learn locally by performing K0subscript𝐾0K_{0} steps of LocalSGD with learning rate γ​η0𝛾subscript𝜂0\gamma\eta_{0} (line 10). As one can see, our approach has the same computation and communication costs at the clients as the usual FL framework.

Note that our algorithm is similar to the incremental (stochastic) gradient method, which has been shown to be much faster than the non-incremental gradient method when the model is far from a (locally) optimal point [2]. While FL with local SGD also works in an incremental fashion, it often needs small learning rates, hence longer learning times, to ensure convergence when the distribution of clients’ data is heterogeneous.

Before presenting a formal analysis and experimental results, let us provide some insights into FSL. First, when the distributions of 𝒟0subscript𝒟0\mathcal{D}_{0} and 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} are close, server’s loss function f0subscript𝑓0f_{0} will be similar to the overall loss function F𝐹F in (1). Consequently, if the current model is far from an optimal point, the gradient ∇f0∇subscript𝑓0\nabla f_{0} will track the global gradient ∇F∇𝐹\nabla F, even when individual clients’ gradients ∇fi∇subscript𝑓𝑖\nabla f_{i} do not follow ∇F∇𝐹\nabla F closely. Therefore, when the updated model obtained by aggregating clients’ updated models does not make (much) progress, ∇f0∇subscript𝑓0\nabla f_{0} will help improve the updated model. In fact, it turns out that significant improvements can still be achieved even when the distributions of 𝒟0subscript𝒟0\mathcal{D}_{0} and 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} are not very similar as long as their difference is small in relation to the non-IIDness of clients’ data. We will elaborate on these points in the following section.

III Convergence Results

We first show in subsection III-A that SL can be viewed as a correction step for FL in the case of non-IID training data. Then the main convergence results are provided in subsection III-B.

III-A SL as Corrections to FL When Far from Convergence

In order to simplify our discussion presented in this subsection which provides key intuition behind our approach, assume that the server can compute gradient ∇f0​(x)∇subscript𝑓0𝑥\nabla f_{0}(x), x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, and consider the usual gradient descent (GD) method for SL. First, consider a single update carried out by the server using GD, starting with some model w0subscript𝑤0w_{0}, i.e., w1=w0−η0​∇f0​(w0)subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤0subscript𝜂0∇subscript𝑓0subscript𝑤0w_{1}=w_{0}-\eta_{0}\nabla f_{0}(w_{0}). Suppose that ∇F∇𝐹\nabla F is Lipschitz continuous with parameter L𝐿L.222This assumption is standard in FL and often holds when training neural networks. We will state this assumption formally in Section III-B. Then,

F​(w1)−F​(w0)𝐹subscript𝑤1𝐹subscript𝑤0\displaystyle F(w_{1})-F(w_{0}) ≤⟨∇F​(w0),w1−w0⟩+0.5​L​‖w1−w0‖2absent∇𝐹subscript𝑤0subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤00.5𝐿superscriptnormsubscript𝑤1subscript𝑤02\displaystyle\leq\left<\nabla F(w_{0}),w_{1}-w_{0}\right>+0.5L\|w_{1}-w_{0}\|^{2}
≤−η0​⟨∇F​(w0),∇f0​(w0)⟩+0.5​L​η02​‖∇f0​(w0)‖2.absentsubscript𝜂0∇𝐹subscript𝑤0∇subscript𝑓0subscript𝑤00.5𝐿superscriptsubscript𝜂02superscriptnorm∇subscript𝑓0subscript𝑤02\displaystyle\leq-\eta_{0}\left<\nabla F(w_{0}),\nabla f_{0}(w_{0})\right>+0.5L\eta_{0}^{2}\|\nabla f_{0}(w_{0})\|^{2}. (7)

The above inequality indicates that SL can improve FL further when the second term in (7) is sufficiently negative so that

2​⟨∇F​(w0),∇f0​(w0)⟩>L​η0​‖∇f0​(w0)‖2.2∇𝐹subscript𝑤0∇subscript𝑓0subscript𝑤0𝐿subscript𝜂0superscriptnorm∇subscript𝑓0subscript𝑤02\displaystyle 2\left<\nabla F(w_{0}),\nabla f_{0}(w_{0})\right>>L\eta_{0}\|\nabla f_{0}(w_{0})\|^{2}. (8)

This condition holds when ∇f0​(w0)∇subscript𝑓0subscript𝑤0\nabla f_{0}(w_{0}) makes an acute angle with ∇F​(w0)∇𝐹subscript𝑤0\nabla F(w_{0}) (provided that ‖∇F​(w0)‖>0norm∇𝐹subscript𝑤00\|\nabla F(w_{0})\|>0), in which case progress can be made by using a sufficiently small step size η0subscript𝜂0\eta_{0}. This will likely be the case when the distribution of 𝒟0subscript𝒟0\mathcal{D}_{0} is similar to that of 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} and, when w0subscript𝑤0w_{0} is far from a (local) minimizer, −∇f0​(w0)∇subscript𝑓0subscript𝑤0-\nabla f_{0}(w_{0}) will likely be a descent direction of F𝐹F at w0subscript𝑤0w_{0}.

In order to further see the role of 𝒟0subscript𝒟0\mathcal{D}_{0}, let us rewrite condition (8) as follows:

‖∇F​(w0)‖2+(1−L​η0)​‖∇f0​(w0)‖2>‖∇F​(w0)−∇f0​(w0)‖2.superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝑤021𝐿subscript𝜂0superscriptnorm∇subscript𝑓0subscript𝑤02superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝑤0∇subscript𝑓0subscript𝑤02\displaystyle\|\nabla F(w_{0})\|^{2}+(1-L\eta_{0})\|\nabla f_{0}(w_{0})\|^{2}>\|\nabla F(w_{0})-\nabla f_{0}(w_{0})\|^{2}. (9)

This implies the following. First, the error ‖∇F​(w0)−∇f0​(w0)‖2superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝑤0∇subscript𝑓0subscript𝑤02\|\nabla F(w_{0})-\nabla f_{0}(w_{0})\|^{2} in general depends on relationship between the server’s dataset 𝒟0subscript𝒟0\mathcal{D}_{0} and the aggregate dataset 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}; the more dissimilar 𝒟0subscript𝒟0\mathcal{D}_{0} is to 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}, the larger the error and thus the smaller the improvement. In fact, SL can have negative impact if the error is sufficiently large. This suggests that the server dataset should be selected carefully in order to maximize the benefits of SL. As an example, consider 𝒟0subscript𝒟0\mathcal{D}_{0} consisting of IID samples. In this case, the error ‖∇F​(w0)−∇f0​(w0)‖2superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝑤0∇subscript𝑓0subscript𝑤02\|\nabla F(w_{0})-\nabla f_{0}(w_{0})\|^{2} tends to decrease with the size of 𝒟0subscript𝒟0\mathcal{D}_{0} according to (sampling without replacement)

𝔼𝒟0​‖∇f0​(x)−∇F​(x)‖2=(nn0−1)​σ~02​(x)n−1,subscript𝔼subscript𝒟0superscriptnorm∇subscript𝑓0𝑥∇𝐹𝑥2𝑛subscript𝑛01superscriptsubscript~𝜎02𝑥𝑛1\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathcal{D}_{0}}\|\nabla f_{0}(x)-\nabla F(x)\|^{2}=\Big{(}\frac{n}{n_{0}}-1\Big{)}\frac{\tilde{\sigma}_{0}^{2}(x)}{n-1}, (10)

where σ~02​(x)=1n​∑s∈𝒟‖∇xℓ​(x,s)−∇F​(x)‖2superscriptsubscript~𝜎02𝑥1𝑛subscript𝑠𝒟superscriptnormsubscript∇𝑥ℓ𝑥𝑠∇𝐹𝑥2\tilde{\sigma}_{0}^{2}(x)=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{s\in\mathcal{D}}\|\nabla_{x}\ell(x,s)-\nabla F(x)\|^{2} is the population variance. Thus, condition (9) can be satisfied by increasing n0subscript𝑛0n_{0}.

Second, for fixed 𝒟0subscript𝒟0\mathcal{D}_{0} (of reasonable quality), the inequality in (9) holds when ‖∇F​(w0)‖norm∇𝐹subscript𝑤0\|\nabla F(w_{0})\| is large, i.e., w0subscript𝑤0w_{0} is far from being a stationary point, which is expected at the beginning of the training process. This is true even when ∇f0​(x)∇subscript𝑓0𝑥\nabla f_{0}(x) is a biased estimate of ∇F​(x)∇𝐹𝑥\nabla F(x) as long as ‖∇F​(w0)−∇f0​(w0)‖2superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝑤0∇subscript𝑓0subscript𝑤02\|\nabla F(w_{0})-\nabla f_{0}(w_{0})\|^{2} is strictly smaller than ‖∇F​(w0)‖2+‖∇f0​(w0)‖2superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝑤02superscriptnorm∇subscript𝑓0subscript𝑤02\|\nabla F(w_{0})\|^{2}+\|\nabla f_{0}(w_{0})\|^{2}, i.e., the angle between the gradients is acute as mentioned earlier, for a sufficiently small step size η0subscript𝜂0\eta_{0}. Third, when ‖∇f0​(w0)‖norm∇subscript𝑓0subscript𝑤0\|\nabla f_{0}(w_{0})\| is sufficiently small, e.g., when overfitting happens at the server, the improvement by SL is also insignificant. Finally, when w0subscript𝑤0w_{0} is near a stationary point of F𝐹F but far from that of f0subscript𝑓0f_{0}, i.e., ‖∇F​(w0)‖≪‖∇f0​(w0)‖much-less-thannorm∇𝐹subscript𝑤0norm∇subscript𝑓0subscript𝑤0\|\nabla F(w_{0})\|\ll\|\nabla f_{0}(w_{0})\|, the inequality in (9) may be reversed, in which case SL can impair FL, pushing the model toward server’s local stationary points. In this case, our algorithm does not yield exact convergence but oscillates between stationary points of F𝐹F and f0subscript𝑓0f_{0}, which is expected for an incremental gradient method [2]. Such convergence will be analyzed in details in the next subsection.

The above analysis also applies when the server performs multiple updates. In particular, suppose that the server performs K0subscript𝐾0K_{0} updates of the model using the GD method with a fixed step size η0subscript𝜂0\eta_{0}:

wt,k+1=wt,k−η0​∇f0​(wt,k),k=0,…,K0−1,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑤𝑡𝑘1subscript𝑤𝑡𝑘subscript𝜂0∇subscript𝑓0subscript𝑤𝑡𝑘𝑘0…subscript𝐾01\displaystyle w_{t,k+1}=w_{t,k}-\eta_{0}\nabla f_{0}(w_{t,k}),\quad k=0,\ldots,K_{0}-1,

with wt,0=x¯tsubscript𝑤𝑡0subscript¯𝑥𝑡w_{t,0}=\bar{x}_{t} and xt+1=wt,K0subscript𝑥𝑡1subscript𝑤𝑡subscript𝐾0x_{t+1}=w_{t,K_{0}}. Then, repeating the steps above and summing over the iterations, we obtain

F​(xt+1)−F​(x¯t)𝐹subscript𝑥𝑡1𝐹subscript¯𝑥𝑡\displaystyle F(x_{t+1})-F(\bar{x}_{t}) ≤−0.5​η0​∑k=0K0−1(‖∇F​(wt,k)‖2+(1−L​η0)​‖∇f0​(wt,k)‖2)absent0.5subscript𝜂0superscriptsubscript𝑘0subscript𝐾01superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝑤𝑡𝑘21𝐿subscript𝜂0superscriptnorm∇subscript𝑓0subscript𝑤𝑡𝑘2\displaystyle\leq-0.5\eta_{0}\textstyle\sum_{k=0}^{K_{0}-1}\big{(}\|\nabla F(w_{t,k})\|^{2}+(1-L\eta_{0})\|\nabla f_{0}(w_{t,k})\|^{2}\big{)}
+0.5​η0​∑k=0K0−1‖∇F​(wt,k)−∇f0​(wt,k)‖2.0.5subscript𝜂0superscriptsubscript𝑘0subscript𝐾01superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝑤𝑡𝑘∇subscript𝑓0subscript𝑤𝑡𝑘2\displaystyle\qquad\qquad+0.5\eta_{0}\textstyle\sum_{k=0}^{K_{0}-1}\|\nabla F(w_{t,k})-\nabla f_{0}(w_{t,k})\|^{2}.

Similarly to the single-update case discussed earlier, we can see that carrying out multiple updates at the server is beneficial when wt,ksubscript𝑤𝑡𝑘w_{t,k} is far from being a stationary point of either F𝐹F or f0subscript𝑓0f_{0}, more precisely, ‖∇F​(wt,k)‖2+(1−L​η0)​‖∇f0​(wt,k)‖2>‖∇F​(wt,k)−∇f0​(wt,k)‖2.superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝑤𝑡𝑘21𝐿subscript𝜂0superscriptnorm∇subscript𝑓0subscript𝑤𝑡𝑘2superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝑤𝑡𝑘∇subscript𝑓0subscript𝑤𝑡𝑘2\|\nabla F(w_{t,k})\|^{2}+(1-L\eta_{0})\|\nabla f_{0}(w_{t,k})\|^{2}>\|\nabla F(w_{t,k})-\nabla f_{0}(w_{t,k})\|^{2}. This also suggests that when learning collaboratively with clients, the server should not overfit its own data, which could happen easily when n0subscript𝑛0n_{0} is small.

III-B Convergence Analysis

In this subsection, we study the convergence properties of FSL. Specifically, we will prove that, under suitable conditions on step sizes, FSL converges to a neighborhood of a stationary point of the following modified loss function

F~=11+γ​F+γ1+γ​f0~𝐹11𝛾𝐹𝛾1𝛾subscript𝑓0\tilde{F}=\textstyle\frac{1}{1+\gamma}F+\frac{\gamma}{1+\gamma}f_{0}

which is simply the normalized version of that in (5), where the weight γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0 is chosen by the server. The value of γ𝛾\gamma should depend on the quality of server’s dataset 𝒟0subscript𝒟0\mathcal{D}_{0}: when the distribution of 𝒟0subscript𝒟0\mathcal{D}_{0} is close to that of 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}, a larger value would offer greater benefits. But, our analysis presented below does not assume that their distributions are close. Also, our experimental results demonstrate that the FSL algorithm can deliver significant benefits even when the two distributions differ considerably (see Section IV)

First, we state several assumptions under which our analysis of Algorithm 1 is carried out.

Assumption 1.

The server and client’s local loss functions {fi}i=0Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑖0𝑁\{f_{i}\}_{i=0}^{N} are L𝐿L-smooth on ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}.

This assumption is standard in the literature and is often satisfied in practice. It also implies that the global loss functions F𝐹F and F~~𝐹\tilde{F} are L𝐿L-smooth. The second assumption is used to bound the gradient dissimilarity caused by clients’ non-IID data; see, e.g., [23].

Assumption 2.

There exists a finite constant G𝐺G such that 1N​∑i∈[N]‖∇fi​(x)−∇F​(x)‖2≤G21𝑁subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑁superscriptnorm∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥∇𝐹𝑥2superscript𝐺2\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i\in[N]}\|\nabla f_{i}(x)-\nabla F(x)\|^{2}\leq G^{2} for all x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Here, G𝐺G bounds the average disparity between the gradients of clients’ loss functions and the empirical loss caused by non-IID samples at the clients; the IID case corresponds to G→0→𝐺0G\to 0. Similarly, when the distributions of 𝒟0subscript𝒟0\mathcal{D}_{0} and 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} are different, there can be a discrepancy between ∇f0∇subscript𝑓0\nabla f_{0} and ∇F∇𝐹\nabla F. We use the following assumption to characterize the quality of server dataset 𝒟0subscript𝒟0\mathcal{D}_{0}.

Assumption 3.

There exists a finite constant ξ¯¯𝜉\bar{\xi} such that ‖∇f0​(x)−∇F​(x)‖2≤ξ¯2superscriptnorm∇subscript𝑓0𝑥∇𝐹𝑥2superscript¯𝜉2\|\nabla f_{0}(x)-\nabla F(x)\|^{2}\leq\bar{\xi}^{2} for all x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

This assumption does not imply that the server data distribution is similar to that of the clients’ aggregate data (although this would be an ideal situation). In other words, ξ¯2superscript¯𝜉2\bar{\xi}^{2} is not necessarily small, and our analysis presented below examines how this bound affects the performance of FSL.

Note that the uniform bounds in Assumptions 2 and 3 are introduced to simplify presentation; what we need in our analysis is that the bounds hold for the sequence {xt}t≥0subscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑡0\{x_{t}\}_{t\geq 0} generated by our algorithm. This holds, for example, when {xt}subscript𝑥𝑡\{x_{t}\} is bounded. Although those bounds are usually unknown, they quantify the extent of non-IIDness in clients’ and server’s data and facilitate our analysis.

Finally, we assume that the clients and the server can obtain unbiased noisy estimates of the gradient of their local loss functions for updating their local models.This assumption is also standard in stochastic optimization.

Assumption 4.

All clients i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N] and the server (i=0𝑖0i=0) have access to unbiased estimates gisubscript𝑔𝑖g_{i} of ∇fi∇subscript𝑓𝑖\nabla f_{i} with variance bounded by σi2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2\sigma_{i}^{2}. For simplicity, we further assume that σi=σsubscript𝜎𝑖𝜎\sigma_{i}=\sigma for all i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N].

Here, σisubscript𝜎𝑖\sigma_{i} only bounds the variance of noisy estimates for the clients and the server. Note that it is not uncommon in practice that the server has enough computing capability so that it can obtain gradient estimates with small variance. For example, when n0subscript𝑛0n_{0} is sufficiently small, the server may utilize all samples to compute the exact gradient for each update, in which case we have σ0=0subscript𝜎00\sigma_{0}=0.

Let us now briefly describe the idea to prove the convergence of FSL. For the special case when N=1𝑁1N=1, K=1𝐾1K=1, and σi=0subscript𝜎𝑖0\sigma_{i}=0, FSL simply reduces to the incremental gradient method. For a general case, we can relate the sequence {xt}subscript𝑥𝑡\{x_{t}\} generated by our algorithm to that of a centralized incremental stochastic gradient method applied to the global loss function F~~𝐹\tilde{F}, where the difference between the two is caused by client sampling and local learning steps. As a result, by choosing step sizes sufficiently small in connection with the bounds in Assumptions 1–4, we can bound such differences and relate the convergence of the two algorithms.

Our first result below demonstrates the progress in one global round of FSL, which resembles that of a centralized stochastic gradient algorithm. Here, we use 𝔼t​[⋅]subscript𝔼𝑡delimited-[]⋅{\mathbb{E}}_{t}[\cdot] to denote the conditional expectation333This conditional expectation is given the σ𝜎\sigma-algebra generated by random variables that determine xtsubscript𝑥𝑡x_{t}. over the randomness at round t𝑡t and define the following:

ρs=N−SN−1,Ψ=γ2​σ02K0+σ2K​S+ρs​G2S.formulae-sequencesubscript𝜌𝑠𝑁𝑆𝑁1Ψsuperscript𝛾2superscriptsubscript𝜎02subscript𝐾0superscript𝜎2𝐾𝑆subscript𝜌𝑠superscript𝐺2𝑆\textstyle\rho_{s}=\frac{N-S}{N-1},\quad\Psi=\frac{\gamma^{2}\sigma_{0}^{2}}{K_{0}}+\frac{\sigma^{2}}{KS}+\frac{\rho_{s}G^{2}}{S}.

Suppose that Assumptions 1–4 hold, and let the step sizes satisfy

K​ηl​ηg=K0​η0≤14​L​min⁡{ηg,1/γ,8/9}.𝐾subscript𝜂𝑙subscript𝜂𝑔subscript𝐾0subscript𝜂014𝐿subscript𝜂𝑔1𝛾89\displaystyle K\eta_{l}\eta_{g}=K_{0}\eta_{0}\leq\textstyle\frac{1}{4L}\min\{\eta_{g},1/\gamma,8/9\}. (11)

Proof:

See Appendix A-A. ∎

We have the following remarks. First, condition (11) means that the server and the clients use the same effective step size per round, which is sufficiently small in the order of 𝒪​(1/L​(1+γ))𝒪1𝐿1𝛾\mathcal{O}(1/L(1+\gamma)). Second, by choosing a sufficiently small K0​η0subscript𝐾0subscript𝜂0K_{0}\eta_{0}, we have h≥1/2ℎ12h\geq 1/2; in fact, it can be shown that if

K0​η0≤18​L​(γ+1)​min⁡{1,(γ+1)22​κ},subscript𝐾0subscript𝜂018𝐿𝛾11superscript𝛾122𝜅K_{0}\eta_{0}\leq\textstyle\frac{1}{8L(\gamma+1)}\min\big{\{}1,\frac{(\gamma+1)^{2}}{2\kappa}\big{\}}, (13)

then h≥3​γ+14ℎ3𝛾14h\geq\frac{3\gamma+1}{4}. Thus, when the current model is far from a stationary point and ‖∇F~​(xt)‖2superscriptnorm∇~𝐹subscript𝑥𝑡2\|\nabla\tilde{F}(x_{t})\|^{2} is large, it is desirable to use large γ𝛾\gamma. But, if γ𝛾\gamma is too large, the last two terms in (12) will likely dominate and prevent the algorithm from making significant improvements, potentially causing it to diverge. Although this suggests that one could use a diminishing γ𝛾\gamma, we consider a fixed γ𝛾\gamma in our analysis for simplicity.

Using the result above, we can quantify the overall progress of the algorithm as follows.

As both ϕitalic-ϕ\phi and κ𝜅\kappa decrease in ηgsubscript𝜂𝑔\eta_{g}, in principle we can select large ηgsubscript𝜂𝑔\eta_{g} to reduce the upper bound in Theorem 2. Here, since we are interested in scenarios where γ=𝒪​(1)𝛾𝒪1\gamma=\mathcal{O}(1) and ρs≈1subscript𝜌𝑠1\rho_{s}\approx 1, ηgsubscript𝜂𝑔\eta_{g} need not be too large either. Based on these observations, let us consider ηg=Θ​(S)subscript𝜂𝑔Θ𝑆\eta_{g}=\Theta(\sqrt{S}), which gives ϕ=Θ​(γ2+1S​(G2+σ2K))italic-ϕΘsuperscript𝛾21𝑆superscript𝐺2superscript𝜎2𝐾\phi=\Theta\big{(}\frac{\gamma^{2}+1}{S}(G^{2}+\frac{\sigma^{2}}{K})\big{)} and thus Φ=𝒪​((γ2+1)​Ψ)Φ𝒪superscript𝛾21Ψ\Phi=\mathcal{O}\big{(}(\gamma^{2}+1)\Psi\big{)}. Under these conditions, we have the following result.

Corollary 1.

If ηg=Θ​(S)subscript𝜂𝑔Θ𝑆\eta_{g}=\Theta(\sqrt{S}), K0=Θ​(K)subscript𝐾0Θ𝐾K_{0}=\Theta(K), K0​η0=Θ​(K​SL​T​(γ+1))subscript𝐾0subscript𝜂0Θ𝐾𝑆𝐿𝑇𝛾1K_{0}\eta_{0}=\Theta\big{(}\frac{\sqrt{KS}}{\sqrt{LT}(\gamma+1)}\big{)}, and condition (13) hold, then

ℰT=𝒪​(LK​S​T​(D~0+M2(γ+1)2)+LT​(M21+γ+γ​κ​K​S​ξ¯2(1+γ)4))subscriptℰ𝑇𝒪𝐿𝐾𝑆𝑇subscript~𝐷0superscript𝑀2superscript𝛾12𝐿𝑇superscript𝑀21𝛾𝛾𝜅𝐾𝑆superscript¯𝜉2superscript1𝛾4\displaystyle\mathcal{E}_{T}\!=\!\mathcal{O}\textstyle\left(\frac{\sqrt{L}}{\sqrt{KST}}\big{(}\tilde{D}_{0}\!+\!\frac{M^{2}}{(\gamma+1)^{2}}\big{)}+\frac{L}{T}\big{(}\frac{M^{2}}{1+\gamma}\!+\!\frac{\gamma\kappa KS\bar{\xi}^{2}}{(1+\gamma)^{4}}\big{)}\right) (14)

with M2=γ2​σ02​S+σ2+ρs​K​G2superscript𝑀2superscript𝛾2superscriptsubscript𝜎02𝑆superscript𝜎2subscript𝜌𝑠𝐾superscript𝐺2M^{2}=\gamma^{2}\sigma_{0}^{2}S+\sigma^{2}+\rho_{s}KG^{2}.

Let us make the following remarks. First, the above sublinear rate of 𝒪​(1T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}}) is to be expected for FL with a nonconvex loss function and is also similar to that of the usual SGD method.

Second, the FedAvg [22] is a special case of FSL with γ=0𝛾0\gamma=0, i.e., without server learning. In this case, M2=σ2+ρs​K​G2superscript𝑀2superscript𝜎2subscript𝜌𝑠𝐾superscript𝐺2M^{2}=\sigma^{2}+\rho_{s}KG^{2} and thus ℰT=𝒪​(LK​S​T​(D~0+M2)+LT​M2)subscriptℰ𝑇𝒪𝐿𝐾𝑆𝑇subscript~𝐷0superscript𝑀2𝐿𝑇superscript𝑀2\mathcal{E}_{T}=\mathcal{O}\big{(}\frac{\sqrt{L}}{\sqrt{KST}}\big{(}\tilde{D}_{0}+M^{2}\big{)}+\frac{L}{T}M^{2}\big{)} is large when clients’ data is highly nonhomogemeous and G2superscript𝐺2G^{2} is large. In this case, increasing γ𝛾\gamma can alleviate the adverse effect of non-IID data, as the dependence on G2superscript𝐺2G^{2} scales as 𝒪​(G2T​(1+γ)2+G2T​(1+γ))𝒪superscript𝐺2𝑇superscript1𝛾2superscript𝐺2𝑇1𝛾\mathcal{O}\big{(}\frac{G^{2}}{\sqrt{T}(1+\gamma)^{2}}+\frac{G^{2}}{T(1+\gamma)}\big{)}, assuming that the last term in (14) is not dominant. This happens when ξ¯2superscript¯𝜉2\bar{\xi}^{2} is small compared to G2superscript𝐺2G^{2} and γ𝛾\gamma is not too large, especially in cases of our interest where σ0≪σmuch-less-thansubscript𝜎0𝜎\sigma_{0}\ll\sigma and ξ¯2≪G2much-less-thansuperscript¯𝜉2superscript𝐺2\bar{\xi}^{2}\ll G^{2}. We discuss two examples scenarios: (1) The server samples are taken from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} via uniform sampling without replacement444In this case, ξ¯¯𝜉\bar{\xi} tends to decrease with the size of 𝒟0subscript𝒟0\mathcal{D}_{0} according to 𝔼𝒟0​‖∇f0​(x)−∇F​(x)‖2=(nn0−1)​σ~02​(x)n−1subscript𝔼subscript𝒟0superscriptnorm∇subscript𝑓0𝑥∇𝐹𝑥2𝑛subscript𝑛01superscriptsubscript~𝜎02𝑥𝑛1{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathcal{D}_{0}}\|\nabla f_{0}(x)-\nabla F(x)\|^{2}=\big{(}\frac{n}{n_{0}}-1\big{)}\frac{\tilde{\sigma}_{0}^{2}(x)}{n-1}, where σ~02​(x)=1n​∑s∈𝒟‖∇xℓ​(x,s)−∇F​(x)‖2superscriptsubscript~𝜎02𝑥1𝑛subscript𝑠𝒟superscriptnormsubscript∇𝑥ℓ𝑥𝑠∇𝐹𝑥2\tilde{\sigma}_{0}^{2}(x)=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{s\in\mathcal{D}}\|\nabla_{x}\ell(x,s)-\nabla F(x)\|^{2} is the population variance. (2) In the applications we target, such as AVs, the manufacturers can likely ensure that the samples collected by test vehicles are more diverse and representative (than those of a typical client) as the collection process is under their control. Thus, it is likely that the server’s data would be more representative than those of a typical “single” client and ξ¯2superscript¯𝜉2\bar{\xi}^{2} is likely much smaller than G2superscript𝐺2G^{2}. We will experiment with these scenarios in the following section.

Third, note that D~0=D0+γ​(f0​(x0)−f0​(x~∗))1+γsubscript~𝐷0subscript𝐷0𝛾subscript𝑓0subscript𝑥0subscript𝑓0superscript~𝑥1𝛾\tilde{D}_{0}=\frac{D_{0}+\gamma(f_{0}(x_{0})-f_{0}(\tilde{x}^{*}))}{1+\gamma}, where D0=F​(x0)−F​(x~∗)subscript𝐷0𝐹subscript𝑥0𝐹superscript~𝑥D_{0}=F(x_{0})-F(\tilde{x}^{*}) and x~∗superscript~𝑥\tilde{x}^{*} is any global minimizer of F~~𝐹\tilde{F}. If x0subscript𝑥0x_{0} is chosen far from x~∗superscript~𝑥\tilde{x}^{*} or a stationary point and the distributions of 𝒟0subscript𝒟0\mathcal{D}_{0} and 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} are similar, it is likely that D~0subscript~𝐷0\tilde{D}_{0} is large and D~0≈D0subscript~𝐷0subscript𝐷0\tilde{D}_{0}\approx D_{0}. On the other hand, if the server pre-trains its model using its own data so as to minimize f0subscript𝑓0f_{0}, then D~0subscript~𝐷0\tilde{D}_{0} can be improved. In fact, because of small size of the server dataset, overfitting can happen and thus f0​(x0)≈0subscript𝑓0subscript𝑥00f_{0}(x_{0})\approx 0 and D~0≤D01+γsubscript~𝐷0subscript𝐷01𝛾\tilde{D}_{0}\leq\frac{D_{0}}{1+\gamma}. This shows that both pre-training and increasing γ𝛾\gamma help.

Forth, the first term of the bound in (14) often dominates and scales as 𝒪​(D~0+γ2​σ02​S+σ2K​S​T+ρs​K​G2S​T)𝒪subscript~𝐷0superscript𝛾2superscriptsubscript𝜎02𝑆superscript𝜎2𝐾𝑆𝑇subscript𝜌𝑠𝐾superscript𝐺2𝑆𝑇\mathcal{O}(\frac{\tilde{D}_{0}+\gamma^{2}\sigma_{0}^{2}S+\sigma^{2}}{\sqrt{KST}}+\frac{\rho_{s}\sqrt{K}G^{2}}{\sqrt{ST}}). This implies that while increasing K𝐾K helps reduce the effect of stochastic noises and initialization, it increases client and server drifts and consequently amplifies the effect of non-IIDness (via the terms K​G2T​S𝐾superscript𝐺2𝑇𝑆\frac{\sqrt{K}G^{2}}{\sqrt{TS}} and K​ρs​G2T+K​ξ¯2T𝐾subscript𝜌𝑠superscript𝐺2𝑇𝐾superscript¯𝜉2𝑇\frac{K\rho_{s}G^{2}}{T}+\frac{K\bar{\xi}^{2}}{T}). Similarly, increasing S𝑆S will reduce the dominant term, which scales as 𝒪​(1S)𝒪1𝑆\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{\sqrt{S}}), at the cost of slightly increasing the smaller term 𝒪​(S​ξ¯2T)𝒪𝑆superscript¯𝜉2𝑇\mathcal{O}(\frac{S\bar{\xi}^{2}}{T}).

Finally, let us remark on the optimality of the original loss. Since ‖∇F​(xt)‖2≤(1+γ)​‖∇F~​(xt)‖2+γ1+γ​ξ¯2superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝑥𝑡21𝛾superscriptnorm∇~𝐹subscript𝑥𝑡2𝛾1𝛾superscript¯𝜉2\|\nabla F(x_{t})\|^{2}\leq(1+\gamma)\|\nabla\tilde{F}(x_{t})\|^{2}+\frac{\gamma}{1+\gamma}\bar{\xi}^{2}, it follows that mint≤T−1⁡𝔼​‖∇F​(xt)‖2≤(1+γ)​ℰT+γ1+γ​ξ¯2subscript𝑡𝑇1𝔼superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝑥𝑡21𝛾subscriptℰ𝑇𝛾1𝛾superscript¯𝜉2\min_{t\leq T-1}{\mathbb{E}}\|\nabla F(x_{t})\|^{2}\leq(1+\gamma)\mathcal{E}_{T}+\frac{\gamma}{1+\gamma}\bar{\xi}^{2}. Here, ℰTsubscriptℰ𝑇\mathcal{E}_{T} can be bounded using Corollary 1, while the second term affects the neighborhood to which the model converges. Thus, in principle, one should select γ𝛾\gamma judiciously to trade off between these two terms. However, we show numerically in the next section that this can be done fairly easily.

IV Experimental Results

We now illustrate the benefits of FSL through experiments using two datasets CIFAR-10 [15] and EMNIST [5].

IV-A Setup

Data and Model: For CIFAR-10 and EMNIST, we use, respectively, 50k samples with 10 label classes and 108k samples with 45 label classes for training. Each dataset also has 10k samples for testing. For simplicity, we partition the nnn training samples roughly evenly among NNN clients so that each client iii has ni=nNsubscriptninNn_{i}\!=\!\frac{n}{N} samples of CCC label classes. Each client will have niCsubscriptniC\frac{n_{i}}{C} samples per label class, selected uniformly at random without replacement from training data. We vary CCC to study the effect of client data heterogeneity – smaller CCC represents more non-IID client data. We use neural networks with two convolutional layers and two dense hidden layers and cross-entropy as the loss function for training; see Appendix B-A for further details.

Methods We compare our approach FSL against (1) Federated Learning FedAvg (FL) [22], (2) FL combined with Data Sharing (DS) [33] that requires sharing among all clients a common dataset comprising samples uniformly distributed over classes, (3) FedDyn [7] which requires additional client storage to retain their state, and (4) SCAFFOLD [14] that doubles communication overheads compared to other methods. For FSL, we assume that the server dataset 𝒟0subscript𝒟0\mathcal{D}_{0} has n0subscript𝑛0n_{0} samples taken from the training data. To facilitate comparison, we use 𝒟0subscript𝒟0\mathcal{D}_{0} as the dataset shared among clients in DS. We also tested FSL with non-incremental SL (§ II), but put its results in Appendix B-B2 for reference as it underperforms FSL.

Implementation Each client chosen by the server at each round trains its local model for EcsubscriptEcE_{c} epochs using local data with batch size BBB. In FSL, the server also updates its model for EssubscriptEsE_{s} epochs in each round using batch size B0subscriptB0B_{0}. Here, we fix Ec=1subscriptEc1E_{c}=1, Es=⌈nN​n0​Ec⌉subscriptEsnNsubscriptn0subscriptEcE_{s}=\lceil\frac{n}{Nn_{0}}E_{c}\rceil, B0=BsubscriptB0BB_{0}=B, ηg=SsubscriptηgS\eta_{g}=\sqrt{S}, and set η0=S​ηl​K/K0subscriptη0SsubscriptηlKsubscriptK0\eta_{0}=\sqrt{S}\eta_{l}K/K_{0}.

Evaluations We run all algorithms for T=1,000𝑇1000T=1,000 rounds, and compare their test accuracy (averaged using a rolling window of size 20) and convergence time measured by rise time, which we define as the first time the test accuracy reaches 90%percent9090\% of the final accuracy. The reported numbers are the averages of 3 runs.

We consider the following two scenarios (which mimic the settings in [33] and [14], respectively): (1) N𝑁N is small, and server data are IID and of small size compared to client’s data, and (2) N𝑁N is large, server data are non-IID, and client data size is relatively small.

IV-B Scenario 1

Consider (N,ni,n0)=(10,5000,500)𝑁subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑛0105000500(N,n_{i},n_{0})=(10,5000,500) for CIFAR-10 and (45,2400,225)452400225(45,2400,225) for EMNIST. Here, 𝒟0subscript𝒟0\mathcal{D}_{0} has roughly n0Csubscript𝑛0𝐶\frac{n_{0}}{C} samples per label class, sampled without replacement from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. We study the role of different parameters in FSL and compare it against FL and DS. Both DS and FSL use a pretrain step where the server trains its local model using SGD with learning rate of 0.010.010.01 for 500500500 epochs over its data 𝒟0subscript𝒟0\mathcal{D}_{0} with batch size B𝐵B. We varied γ∈{N​n0n,0.5,1,1.5,2}𝛾𝑁subscript𝑛0𝑛0.511.52\gamma\in\{\frac{Nn_{0}}{n},0.5,1,1.5,2\}; note that when γ=N​n0n𝛾𝑁subscript𝑛0𝑛\gamma=\frac{Nn_{0}}{n}, FSL has the same (global) objective as DS.

Effects of Client Data Distributions: Fig. 1 shows the test accuracy as we vary CCC to create different levels of non-IIDness. We have the following observations.

First, all algorithms achieve a similar final accuracy in the IID case (C=45C45C=45 for EMNIST and C=10C10C=10 for CIFAR-10). But, when client data become more non-IID as CCC decreases, FL suffers significantly in both accuracy and convergence time, which is expected and well reported in the literature. Second, DS greatly improves over FL, but has a similar convergence property: slower learning with wide oscillations. This is to be expected as DS is essentially FL where each client has an additional small set of shared data. Third, in all cases, FSL provides the highest accuracy and fastest convergence with considerable acceleration at the beginning and much smaller oscillations in accuracy, thanks to only a small dataset at the server (which is about 0.21%percent0.210.21\% of training data for EMNIST and 1%percent11\% for CIFAR-10). Fourth, FSL performs fairly consistently for a range of γγ\gamma values, suggesting that fine tuning might be unnecessary. Finally, although we use a pretrained model for FSL and DS but not FL, we show in Appendix B-B1 that similar observations can be obtained when FSL, DS, and FL all use the same initial model. In fact, FSL provides more significant acceleration, even in the IID cases, whereas DS offers little to no benefits over FL.

Benefits of Server Learning: Fig. 2 plots the accuracy and rise time of FSL when varying the weight γ𝛾\gamma, learning rate ηlsubscript𝜂𝑙\eta_{l}, and server data size n0subscript𝑛0n_{0}.

Role of γ𝛾\gamma: First, in general, increasing γ𝛾\gamma from 00 improves the accuracy and convergence time significantly compared to DS. The improvement is more pronounced when comparing to FL. Second, such improvements remain significant over a wide range of γ𝛾\gamma values. For example, γ𝛾\gamma over [0.5,1.5]0.51.5[0.5,1.5] provides similar performance for all considered local learning rates ηlsubscript𝜂𝑙\eta_{l}, server data sizes n0subscript𝑛0n_{0}, and for both datasets. For CIFAR-10, it appears that a smaller γ𝛾\gamma provides better results, while a large value may slightly degrade the performance; the opposite holds true for EMNIST (except when C=1𝐶1C=1 and ηlsubscript𝜂𝑙\eta_{l} is large, increasing γ>1𝛾1\gamma>1 actually decreases the accuracy). This can be attributed to the fact that the client data are more non-IID and server samples are more dissimilar in CIFAR-10 than in EMNIST; see the cases C=2𝐶2C=2 and C=5𝐶5C=5 in Fig. 1.

Server data size: First, with a small (good quality) dataset, the server can already have a pretrained model much better than random initialization. Second, it is clear that increasing the server data size helps improve FSL further. Here, the accuracy improvement is greater for CIFAR-10 than EMNIST. The rise time improvement is significant when ηlsubscript𝜂𝑙\eta_{l} is small and diminishes for larger ηlsubscript𝜂𝑙\eta_{l}. Note that increasing the local learning rate ηlsubscript𝜂𝑙\eta_{l} also increases the server’s effective learning rate, which is γ​η0=γ​ηl​S𝛾subscript𝜂0𝛾subscript𝜂𝑙𝑆\gamma\eta_{0}=\gamma\eta_{l}\sqrt{S}.

IV-C Scenario 2

Consider (N,ni)=𝑁subscript𝑛𝑖absent(N,n_{i})= (1000, 50) for CIFAR-10 and (450, 240) for EMNIST. Unlike in Scenario 1, we now consider two different sources of data for the server.

Data from a few clients

The server obtains data only from a subset of c𝑐c clients,555These clients can be, for example, test vehicles in our AV example; here they are sampled without replacement once prior to training for simplicity. each contributing s𝑠s samples (selected uniformly at random without replacement). Here (c,s,n0)=(10,50,500)𝑐𝑠subscript𝑛01050500(c,s,n_{0})=(10,50,500) for CIFAR-10 and (9,50,450)950450(9,50,450) for EMNIST. Note that the server data is imbalanced and non-IID (likely missing one or more label classes when C=1𝐶1C=1).

Data from other source(s)

For EMNIST, we provide the server n0=675subscript𝑛0675n_{0}=675 synthetic examples by generating for each label class 15 images of the corresponding letter or number using a cursive font with 5 rotation angles {−20,−10,0,10,20}201001020\{-20,-10,0,10,20\} and 3 sizes;666To generate synthetic data, we first plot each character or number in a 2 inch ×\times 2 inch figure using font sizes {100,110,120}100110120\{100,110,120\} in points with each point equal to 1/721721/72 inch, and then resize it to a 28 pixel ×\times 28 pixel figure. see Fig. 3 for a comparison of this synthetic data and EMNIST. For CIFAR-10, we collect n0=504subscript𝑛0504n_{0}=504 images from the dataset STL-10 with 9 similar label classes as in CIFAR-10, each with 56 examples;777STL-10 images were acquired from labeled examples on ImageNet; data available at: https://cs.stanford.edu/∼similar-to\simacoates/stl10/ see Fig. 4 for an illustration of this data, and note that the class frog is absent in STL-10. We refer to our algorithm in this case as FSLsyn. Our goal with FSLsyn is to examine the benefits of server learning when it is performed on data with a significantly different distribution than that of clients’ data.

We compare FSL and FSLsyn (without using a pretrained model) against SCAFFOLD and FedDyn when S=⌈N/100⌉𝑆𝑁100S=\lceil N/100\rceil. We use ηg=Ssubscript𝜂𝑔𝑆\eta_{g}=\sqrt{S} for FSL, FSLsyn, and SCAFFOLD. Fig. 5 shows the test accuracy after T=1,000𝑇1000T=1,000 rounds with varying learning rate ηlsubscript𝜂𝑙\eta_{l} and non-IIDness C𝐶C. Here, we fix the weight γ=1𝛾1\gamma\!=\!1 in FSL and FSLsyn and regularization parameter α=0.01𝛼0.01\alpha=0.01 in FedDyn; better performance can be obtained by tuning these parameters as we will show later. First, it shows that, compared to SCAFFOLD and FedDyn, our algorithms FSL and FSLsyn have comparable overall accuracy for EMNIST and much better for CIFAR-10, especially in very non-IID cases, even without tuning γ𝛾\gamma. The heatmap also suggests that it is fairly easy to select learning rates for FSL and FSLsyn. The results further indicate that using server learning with synthetic or other ‘good’ sources of data can provide significant benefits. In fact, FSLsyn has comparable performance to FSL for EMNIST and slightly worse performance for CIFAR-10 (but still better than FedDyn and SCAFFOLD in this case). Additional experimental results reported in Figures 10 and 11 in Appendix B-B4 also show that FSL and FSLsyn have faster rise times in most cases. Note that our algorithm can be improved further by having more (and better) data for server learning and using a pretraining step.

Finally, Table 1 shows that both the quantity and the quality of server’s data 𝒟0subscript𝒟0\mathcal{D}_{0} affect the performance of FSL. These results are obtained with CIFAR-10 when clients’ data is highly non-IID with C=2𝐶2C=2, and we pick the learning rates according to the highest accuracy given in Fig. 5. We also fine-tune the regularization parameter of FedDyn with α∈{0.01,0.05,0.1,0.5}𝛼0.010.050.10.5\alpha\in\{0.01,0.05,0.1,0.5\} following [7] and the server weight γ∈{0.6,0.8,1.0,1.2}𝛾0.60.81.01.2\gamma\in\{0.6,0.8,1.0,1.2\} in FSL and FSLsyn – we report the best numbers and skip SCAFFOLD as it underperforms FedDyn. Moreover, we vary the server data size n0∈{250,500}subscript𝑛0250500n_{0}\in\{250,500\} for FSL, and n0∈{504,720}subscript𝑛0504720n_{0}\in\{504,720\} for FSLsyn. Both the rise time and the accuracy improve as n0subscript𝑛0n_{0} increases, with FSL featuring a more significant improvement since the server’s data are more similar to the clients’ data compared to synthetic data (see Fig. 4). In addition, both of our algorithms require a significantly smaller number of global rounds to reach 0.5 accuracy, showcasing the benefit of server learning. It is also interesting to note that FSL with n0=250subscript𝑛0250n_{0}=250 is still slightly better than FSLsyn with n0=720subscript𝑛0720n_{0}=720, confirming that the synthetic data are likely taken from a different distribution.

V Conclusions

We considered a new approach to mitigate the performance degradation of FL on non-IID data. Our approach augments FL with server learning using a small dataset, and thus is complementary in that it can be utilized in conjunction with other existing approaches in the literature. Our analysis and experiments revealed that FSL can offer significant improvements in terms of accuracy and convergence time over conventional FL algorithms, even when the server dataset is relatively small. As expected, the improvements depend not only on server data size but also on the divergence between its distribution and that of the aggregate training data. The improvements are higher when the distributional divergence is smaller. We are currently exploring the issue of choosing a suitable dataset for the server learning and the relationship between the performance improvements and the server data size/the distributional divergence.

Appendix A Proofs

Our proofs will use the following technical lemmas.

Lemma 1.

If {z1,z2,…,zm}subscript𝑧1subscript𝑧2…subscript𝑧𝑚\{z_{1},z_{2},\ldots,z_{m}\} are independent random variables with 0-mean, then 𝔼​[‖∑i=1mzi‖2]=𝔼​[∑i=1m‖zi‖2]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝑧𝑖2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚superscriptnormsubscript𝑧𝑖2{\mathbb{E}}\big{[}\|\sum_{i=1}^{m}z_{i}\|^{2}\big{]}={\mathbb{E}}\big{[}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\|z_{i}\|^{2}\big{]}

Lemma 2.

(CS inequality) The following hold for any {v1,…,vm}⊂ℝdsubscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑚superscriptℝ𝑑\{v_{1},\ldots,v_{m}\}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}:

  • 1.

    ‖vi+vj‖2≤(1+a)​‖vi‖2+(1+1a)​‖vj‖2superscriptnormsubscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝑣𝑗21𝑎superscriptnormsubscript𝑣𝑖211𝑎superscriptnormsubscript𝑣𝑗2\|v_{i}+v_{j}\|^{2}\leq(1+a)\|v_{i}\|^{2}+(1+\frac{1}{a})\|v_{j}\|^{2} for any a>0𝑎0a>0, and

  • 2.

    ‖∑i=1mvi‖2≤m​∑i=1m‖vi‖2superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝑣𝑖2𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚superscriptnormsubscript𝑣𝑖2\|\sum_{i=1}^{m}v_{i}\|^{2}\leq m\sum_{i=1}^{m}\|v_{i}\|^{2}.

We will refer to both inequalities above as the Cauchy-Schwarz (CS) inequality in the rest of this section.

A-E Corollary 1 and its proof

The following results show the convergence error for different step size conditions, which subsume Corollary 1.

Proof.

Note that under condition (13), we have h=Ω​(γ+1)ℎΩ𝛾1h=\Omega(\gamma+1). Thus, the proof follows immediately from dividing both sides of the inequality in Theorem 2 by hℎh and then using the step size conditions in each statement. ∎

A-F Special Cases

Let us show here that our FSL approach includes FedAvg and centralized SGD as special cases.

FedAvg as a Special Case

Clearly, FedAvg is the special case of our formulation with γ→0→𝛾0\gamma\to 0, i.e., there is no server learning. Take Corollary 3.7, for example, although the bound on the RHS is by no means tight, it’s clear that using a positive γ𝛾\gamma will lower RHS (provided ξ¯¯𝜉\bar{\xi} small compared to G𝐺G), especially the coefficient of the dominant error term 1T1𝑇\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}} in the bound, which is D~0+G2(1+γ)2subscript~𝐷0superscript𝐺2superscript1𝛾2\tilde{D}_{0}+\frac{G^{2}}{(1+\gamma)^{2}}. Note also that D~0=𝒪​(D01+γ)subscript~𝐷0𝒪subscript𝐷01𝛾\tilde{D}_{0}=\mathcal{O}(\frac{D_{0}}{1+\gamma}) for small γ𝛾\gamma. We briefly discussed this after Corollary 3.7.

Centralized SGD as a Special Case

Consider the case where Server has access to all training data of clients and thus can just perform local/centralized learning. This extreme case can be approximated by FSL using ξ¯=0¯𝜉0\bar{\xi}=0 and a sufficiently large value of γ𝛾\gamma. Since Corollary 3.7 is for γ=𝒪​(1)𝛾𝒪1\gamma=\mathcal{O}(1), we can use Theorem 3.6 instead.

For large γ𝛾\gamma, we have κ=Θ​(γ3)𝜅Θsuperscript𝛾3\kappa=\Theta(\gamma^{3}). From (9), let us choose K0​η0​L=Θ​(1/γ2)subscript𝐾0subscript𝜂0𝐿Θ1superscript𝛾2K_{0}\eta_{0}L=\Theta(1/\gamma^{2}), which implies h=Θ​(γ)ℎΘ𝛾h=\Theta(\gamma), Φ=Θ​(γ2​Ψ)ΦΘsuperscript𝛾2Ψ\Phi=\Theta(\gamma^{2}\Psi), and Ψ=Θ​(γ2​σ02K0+G~)ΨΘsuperscript𝛾2superscriptsubscript𝜎02subscript𝐾0~𝐺\Psi=\Theta(\frac{\gamma^{2}\sigma_{0}^{2}}{K_{0}}+\tilde{G}) with G~=σ2K​S+ρs​G2S~𝐺superscript𝜎2𝐾𝑆subscript𝜌𝑠superscript𝐺2𝑆\tilde{G}=\frac{\sigma^{2}}{KS}+\frac{\rho_{s}G^{2}}{S}. Let α=η0​γ𝛼subscript𝜂0𝛾\alpha=\eta_{0}\gamma, which is the stepsize of server in Algorithm 1. As a result, Theorem 3.6 implies ℰT=𝒪​(D~T​K0​α+L​σ02​α+G~γ3)subscriptℰ𝑇𝒪~𝐷𝑇subscript𝐾0𝛼𝐿superscriptsubscript𝜎02𝛼~𝐺superscript𝛾3\mathcal{E}_{T}=\mathcal{O}(\frac{\tilde{D}}{TK_{0}\alpha}+L\sigma_{0}^{2}\alpha+\frac{\tilde{G}}{\gamma^{3}}). The first two terms are exactly the error bound of SGD with a fixed stepsize, and the last term is the contribution of clients, which is negligible for large γ𝛾\gamma.

Appendix B Further Numerical Results

In this section, we present detailed models and further simulation results.

B-A Neural Network Models Used in Our Experiments

In our experiments, we use networks with 2 convolutional layers followed by 2 dense layers as shown in Tables II and III. Note that these models are enough for our purpose of illustrations and comparing different algorithms; they are by no means designed to achieve the state-of-the-art accuracy.

B-B Futher Results

B-B1 Test Accuracy Without Using Server Pretrained Model

Figure 6 shows the performance of FSL, FL and DS when they start from a randomly initialized model instead of a pretrained one as in Figure 1. Clearly, in this case, the acceleration provided by SL is much more significant, even in the IID cases, in which DS offers little to no benefits as one would expect.

B-B2 Comparison with Non-incremental SL

Figure 7 compares the performance of FSL, DS and the non-incremental version of SL, denoted by FSL-p, when varying C𝐶C and S𝑆S. Clearly, FSL-p is slightly worse than DS while FSL significantly outperforms in all cases. A similar conclusion can be drawn as we vary γ𝛾\gamma as shown in Figure 8.

B-B3 Quantifying the Non-IIDness of Clients and Server

In general, it is difficult to obtain uniform bounds ξ¯¯𝜉\bar{\xi} and G𝐺G in Assumptions 2–3. Thus, in Figure 9, we show the following two related quantities in some of our experiments: ξt2=‖∇f0​(xt)−∇F​(xt)‖2,superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡2superscriptnorm∇subscript𝑓0subscript𝑥𝑡∇𝐹subscript𝑥𝑡2\xi_{t}^{2}=\|\nabla f_{0}(x_{t})-\nabla F(x_{t})\|^{2}, and Gt2=1N​∑i∈[N]‖∇fi​(xt)−∇F​(xt)‖2superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑡21𝑁subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑁superscriptnorm∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑥𝑡∇𝐹subscript𝑥𝑡2\textstyle G_{t}^{2}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i\in[N]}\|\nabla f_{i}(x_{t})-\nabla F(x_{t})\|^{2} for t=0,50,100,…​1000.𝑡050100…1000t=0,50,100,\ldots 1000. First, it is clear that increasing C𝐶C reduces the non-IIDness considerably in our experiments with both datasets. Second, in most cases and on average, ξt2superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡2\xi_{t}^{2} is much smaller than Gt2superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑡2G_{t}^{2} and is improved when n0subscript𝑛0n_{0} increases. Third, perhaps somewhat surprisingly, even having access to 2 or 5 samples per label (n0=90subscript𝑛090n_{0}=90 and 225225225) in EMNIST dataset already offers FSL a significant advantage to combat the non-IIDness of clients’ data. To have a similar level of benefit for the case of CIFAR-10, many more samples are needed for the server’s data. This is another indication besides final accuracy that in our experiments, EMNIST dataset is easier to learn from even though it has more label classes than CIFAR-10.

B-B4 Further Comparison with FedDyn and SCAFFOLD

Figures 10 and 11 show the test accuracy (averaged over 3 runs) of FSL, FSLsyn, FedDyn, and SCAFFOLD with server step size ηg=Ssubscript𝜂𝑔𝑆\eta_{g}=\sqrt{S} and T=1000𝑇1000T=1000. FSL, FSLsyn not only has comparable (if not better) final accuracy than SCAFFOLD in most cases but also achieves higher initial training acceleration.
